dublin_core.dcvalue: BACKGROUND The referral process in acute care remains challenging in many areas including burn care Mobile phone apps designed explicitly for medical referrals and consultations could streamline the referral process by using structured templates and integrating features specific to different specialties However as these apps are competing with commercial chat services usability becomes a crucial factor for successful uptake OBJECTIVE The aim of this study was to assess the usability of a mobile phone app for remote consultations and referrals of burn injuries METHODS A total of 24 emergency doctors and 4 burns consultants were recruited for the study A mixed methods approach was used including a usability questionnaire and a think aloud interview Think aloud sessions were video recorded and content analysis was undertaken with predefined codes relating to the following 3 themes ease of use usefulness of content and technology induced errors RESULTS The users perceived the app to be easy to use and useful but some problems were identified Issues relating to usability were associated with navigation such as scrolling and zooming Users also had problems in understanding the meaning of some icons and terminologies Sometimes some users felt limited by predefined options and they wanted to be able to freely express their clinical findings CONCLUSIONS We found that users faced problems mainly with navigation when the app did not work in the same way as the other apps that were frequently used Our study also resonates with previous findings that when using standardized templates the systems should also allow the user to express their clinical findings in their own words
